prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Angular resolution and maximum scale: The smallest structure we aim to study is the circumstellar torus (1.5"; Fig 2), while the largest is the total span of the jet (3"; Fig 2). Our setup for resolution (0.25") and maximum scale (3.5") are enough for our goals.
Spectral setup: We will simultaneously observe CO(3-2) and HCO+(4-3). An additional window will be tuned at the less abundant isotope H13CO+(4-3). The fourth spectral window will be for continuum only. With lines ~30 km/s wide, spectral resolutions of 1 km/s are enough. We chose a finer resolution (and will smooth offline as required) while still keeping a low data rate. We will use a wide total bandwidth (~400 km/s) to properly sample low-level high velocity emission (Fig 2)
Sensitivity. We aim at an rms of 0.65 K, to detect at >8 sigma the high-velocity wings in the CO spectrum (5 K with SMA). We have adopted the same brightness temperature for the CO(3-2) line as that observed with the SMA in the CO(2-1). This is a worst-case scenario, which assumes that the CO(2-1) is optically thick and completely fills the SMA beam. Departure from these assumptions would lead to a higher brightness temperature.

Angular resolution and maximum scale: The smallest structure we aim to study is the circumstellar torus (1.5"; Fig 2), while the largest is the total span of the jet (3"; Fig 2). Our setup for resolution (0.25") and maximum scale (3.5") are enough for our goals.
Spectral setup: We will simultaneously observe CO, 13CO, and C18O(2-1) within two basebands (1 & 3). Basebands 2 & 4 are devoted to continuum. However, we set them in spectral mode, since it allows a resolution of ~1.3 km/s at no significant lose for continuum sensitivity. We centered them at two lines whose detection is not guaranteed, but will provide interesting science results if present. With lines ~30 km/s wide, spectral resolutions of 1 km/s are enough. We chose a finer resolution for CO isotopes (and will smooth offline as required) while still keeping a low data rate. The total velocity coverage is limited to 160 km/s to be able to accomodate both CO and 13CO. With this we might miss some high-velocity emission, but it will be amply covered by the spectral windows in band 7
Sensitivity. We aim at an rms of 0.65 K, to detect at >8 sigma the high-velocity wings in the CO spectrum (5 K with SMA). We are assuming the same brightness temperature as in the SMA spectrum, which is a lower limit to the actual one that ALMA will obtain, since the beam of the latter is smaller.

Angular resolution and maximum scale: The smallest structure we aim to study is the circumstellar torus (1.5", based on optical images), while the largest is the total span of the jet (3"; Fig 2). Our setup for resolution (0.25") and maximum scale (3.5") are enough for our goals.
Spectral setup: We will simultaneously observe CO(3-2) and HCO+(4-3). An additional window will be tuned at the less abundant isotope H13CO+(4-3). The fourth spectral window will be for continuum only. With lines ~30 km/s wide, spectral resolutions of 1 km/s are enough. We chose a finer resolution (and will smooth offline as required) while still keeping a low data rate. We will use a wide total bandwidth (~400 km/s) to properly sample low-level high velocity emission that may be present, similar to that seen in I17347 (Fig 2)
Sensitivity. Our lowest estimate for our main target lines is Tb=3.2 K, which is an extremely conservative lower limit. It assumes that the HCO+(1-0) observed at Onsala is already optically thick and therefore, the brightness temperature of the HCO+(4-3) is the same (if this assumption is not correct, the brightness of the (4-3) line will be higher). It also assumes that the line emission extends over an area with 3" diameter, larger than expected. Our requested rms=0.65 K would guarantee detection of CO and HCO+ at significantly more than 5sigma.

Angular resolution and maximum scale: The smallest structure we aim to study is the circumstellar torus (1.5"; based on optical images), while the largest is the total span of the jet (3"; Fig 2). Our setup for resolution (0.25") and maximum scale (3.5") are enough for our goals.
Spectral setup: We will simultaneously observe CO, 13CO, and C18O(2-1) within two basebands (1 & 3). Basebands 2 & 4 are devoted to continuum. However, we set them in spectral mode, since it allows a resolution of ~1.3 km/s at no significant lose for continuum sensitivity. We centered them at two lines whose detection is not guaranteed, but will provide interesting science results if present. With lines ~30 km/s wide, spectral resolutions of 1 km/s are enough. We chose a finer resolution for CO isotopes (and will smooth offline as required) while still keeping a low data rate. The total velocity coverage is limited to 160 km/s to be able to fit both CO and 13CO. With this we might miss some high-velocity emission, but it will be amply covered by the spectral windows in band 7
Sensitivity. Our estimate for the intensity of the CO(2-1) line is 10 K, which is an extremely conservative lower limit. It assumes that the line emission observed with IRAM-30m extends over an area with 3" diameter, much larger than expected. Our requested rms=0.65 K would guarantee detection of CO at significantly more than 10 sigma. Although the 13CO line would lie at ~2 sigma under this assumption, it would be easily detectable at 8 sigma if the size of the emission is ~1.5"

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: There is a growing consensus that collimated jets are the shaping mechanism of PNe, but evidences of this are indirect so far. We propose to image the circumstellar structure of two extremely young planetary nebuale (K3-35 and IRAS 17347-3139) using the CO(3-2) and HCO+(4-3) molecular lines in band 7, as well as CO, 13CO, and C18O in band 6. These objects are unique, since they have water maser emission, something previously unexpected in PNe, and that pinpoints them as objects that have just entered this phase. Our main goals are: (1) Confirm in situ, for the first time, whether high-velocity jets shape PN. (2) Determine the presence of toroidal structures around the objects. (3) Study the energetics of the interaction between jets and circumstellar envelopes. (4) Test whether dense gas is protecting water molecules from ionizing radiation, thus allowing the presence of water masers. Our observations will provide a complete picture of the components of the circumstellar environment of young PNe, their physical conditions and mutual interactions, which will help us to understand this late stage of stellar evolution.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Centro de Radioastronomia y Astrofisica, Universidad Nacional Autonomo de Mexico
Department of Applied Physics, Barcelona Technical University
Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, National Observatory of Athens
Observatoire de la Cote d'Azur Nice
